title: Two pipes A and B can fill a tank in 12 and 16 minutes respectively. Both pipes are opened together, but 4 minutes before the tank is full, one pipe A is closed. How much time will they take to fill the tank? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have developed equation already for 2 types of pipe and is still valid.Asssume the two types are to fill the tank simultaneously, it takes time t t=xy/x+y where x=12 and pipes A and y=16 and pipes B. t will give you 6.86minutes .Good but not there yet. If in 4 minutes before the tank is full you close pipe A which is larger.Pipes A and B would have worked for only 2.86 minutes together and the tank will only be filled by 2.86/6.86 or 41.7% filled and 58.3% empty. It is getting interesting I suppose but not there yet.Now if only pipe B is to fill the tank note that it will take 16minutes confirmed. Now to fill the remaining 58.3% it will take 16*0.583 minutes and you get 9.31minutes.Great we are getting close Remember that both pipes work for 2.86 minutes before pipe A is closed The total time to fill is 2.86+9.31 minutes and you get 12.17 minutes or 12minutes and 10.2 seconds Interesting I suppose the implication is that the pipe B is not not necessary if the system does not need to shut off the pipe A 4 minutes before the tank is filled. In design you incorporate pipe B if the pipe A cannot function more than 3 minutes and you still want to ensure that the tank is filled within 12 minutes.

A can fill in 12 minutes and B in 16 minutes LCM=48 Efficiency A:B 4:3 In 1 minute A fills 4 units and B fills 3units Total time taken to fill the tank 48/7 when both pipes are open. Let ‘t’ be the time pipes are open. However, First pipe is closed 4 minutes before tank gets filled. 4 (t -4) + 3t = 48 4t + 3t =48+16 7t = 64 t = 9-1/7 minutes Time taken to fill the tank is 9-1/7 minutes

Consider total work be 48 units.( LCM of 12 &16) Given, A can fill tank (48 units) in 12 minutes. B can fill tank (48 units) in 16 minutes. Now, we can know that efficiency of: A is 4 units /minute ( Since 48/12=4) and B is 3 units/minute (Since 48/16=3) Also given that, A is closed 4 minutes before the tank is full. Hence, we add that 4 minute work of A to total work and divide by combined efficiency of A & B. Now, 48+(4×4)=64. Then 64/7= 9 1/7 minutes. (Efficiency of A&B =7) Answer is 9 1/7 minutes.

A can fill the tank in 12 min ..So in 1 min it can fill 1/12 part of the tank. B can fill the tank in 16 min… so in 1 min it can fill 1/16 part of the tank. Let time required to fill the tank be 'x' min. That means A was open for (x-4) min and B was open for x min…. Together they complete the task, hence equation will be equated to 1. Hence, 1(x-4)/12 +1(x)/16 = 1 x/12 + x/16 = 1+ (4/3) Which gives x= 192/21 min = 9.14 min approximately Together they will need less time to fill the tank than individually.

So in 4 minutes 12/48 or 25 % Answer It will take 9.1428 minutes to fill this tank in a two stage filling sequence. or 9 minutes & 8.571 seconds

Pipe A in 1 minute fills 1/12 of tank Pipe B in 1 minute fills 1/16 of tank Together in 1 minute they fill 1/12+1/16 = (4+3)/ 48 =7/48 Together they will fill tank in 48/7 minutes So both are open for 48/7 -4 = 20/7 minutes In 20/7 minutes they fill 20/7 x 7/48 =20/48 of tank Remaining to be filled = 28/48= 7/12 Pipe B takes 16 minutes to fill so 7/12 of tank will take 7/12 x16= 28/3 minutes So total time 20/7 +28/3= (60 + 196) /21 = 256/21 = 12.19 minutes ANSWER

let, capacity of the tank is x litres. flow rate through pipe A = (x / 12) litres / minute flow rate through pipe B = (x / 16) litres / minute let, pipe A remains opened for t minutes; so pipe B remains opened for (t + 4) minutes. (x / 12)*t + (x /16)*(t + 4) = x multiplying both sides by (48 / x) 4t + 3(t + 4) = 48 7t = 48 - 12 = 36 t = (36 / 7) ≈5 minutes 08.57 seconds therefore, it will take 9 minutes 08.57 seconds to fill the tank.
